https://t.co/1uDbUBHJ2L https://t.co/KrDdUG0LWm @messenger @FBBusiness 💖We’ll get the deets in the DMs ✨ We want everyone to stay safe on Instagram. For even more tips, visit: https://t.co/wFQcJVz25j If you have a larger following, we’ll notify you in app to make sure you’re keeping your account as safe as possible since you might be more at risk of being targeted. https://t.co/rP58KeEdyd Ever get an email that looks like it could be from IG asking for info? Check your settings to confirm we contacted you. Not there? Then it’s not from us.
 
We’ll also never DM you about account issues, so if you get a support message there, report it.

This #SaferInternetDay, we’ve brought together cyberbullying and child protection experts and t… We want to create a safe and supportive community for everyone on Instagram. For even more tips, visit: https://t.co/Vgco7yma5R To give you more control over who can contact you on Instagram, there’s a new way to limit who can send you direct messages. The feature lets only the people you follow message you and add you to group threads. https://t.co/UyhOpcCAZG We also want to help stop bullying before it happens. If someone writes a potentially offensive comment or caption, they’ll get a prompt saying it’s similar to content that’s been reported for bullying. We’ve found this can encourage people to reconsider what they’re posting. ICYMI, we’ve also been rolling out more features to help prevent bullying. When you restrict an account, only they can see their comments on your posts. And they can’t see when you’ve read their direct messages or when you’re active on Instagram. https://t.co/dOBhxFAITO If your account’s been disabled, there’s a new way to appeal in the app. When you try to log in, you’ll see an option to “Request a Review.” Tap it and we’ll review your disabled account and potentially restore it. We'll roll out these features over the coming weeks. https://t.co/W9r6B7dpau You can also tap “More Options” for suggested actions – like muting, blocking or unfollowing accounts you’ve reported. And if you disagree with our decision on the content, you can request a review and we’ll take a second look. Now when you report something that shouldn’t be on Instagram (like bullying or offensive content), you can get updates through Support Requests. It’s a new feature in the app that shows you the status of your reports. Go to “Settings”  –> “Support Requests.” https://t.co/6hag2ccKtx For #SaferInternetDay, we’re sharing some tips on how to stay safe on Instagram and take more control over your experience❤️ Right now on our story: we're looking at #Oscars night in Instagram hashtags. One of the most important things you can do to prevent hacking is turn on two-factor authentication.

“One of my favorite parts of my job is helping amplify voices that are underrepresented in other forms of media. I truly believe in the power of the internet to create a safe space for marginalized communities.” —Mitzi G., strategic partner manager, creators and emerging talent https://t.co/9MdxsZRRCH

“I’m most proud of myself when I overcome a stressful moment and deliver the results I want, be that a public speaking engagement or making my toddler put on a coat when all she wants is to walk around in her bathing suit all the time.” —Natalia P., head of public policy, LATAM https://t.co/ll1Mv1uQpb

“I was raised in Brazil, and since I was 9 my dream was to work on interactive experiences. I was proud when we shipped Oculus Rift and made VR accessible, allowing people across the globe to have deeper connections and experiences.” —Bruno E., software engineering manager https://t.co/bgGxztO79H

“I believe it’s essential to know who you are and where you come from to decide where to go next. This month is a great time to get in touch with the traditions that make up our culture since it’s the bond that ties us together as a community.” —Anaelisa A., technical artist https://t.co/a7QJAmxeIo

“For me, being Latin means embracing diversity. We take pride in the fact that our skin colors differ, our accents vary and our geography looks like a little bit of everything. This month reminds us no matter how different we are, we’re the same.” —Alvaro G., production engineer https://t.co/uY0cYpuczZ

“As a Puerto Rican, this month has a lot of different meanings, but it feels much different for me today than it ever did before. For me it’s about identity, celebrating intersectionality, creating connection and belonging.” —Kim G., program manager https://t.co/hnQs0CPCLa

“All the people who doubted I could work and be a good mom and wife. All the people that asked what my husband did before getting to know me. They paved the way for me because I wanted to prove them wrong.” —Adriana G., director of business strategy, LATAM https://t.co/7NhSVBTKda

“I’ve realized there’s no one way to be Latinx. Away from my Cubanaso community, I’ve met and grown closer to people whose backgrounds might look different from mine but whose language, vibrance and warmth feel familiar.”  —Caro D., product specialist, Reels and camera https://t.co/gf9i3YLPCH

“I believe it takes a village of supportive communities for each of us to rise up and advance the next generation. My grandpa came from Mexico, working to feed 12 kids. For me to be here, it took my family and so many others’ support along the way.” —Sal B., research manager https://t.co/vRTckKq3H0

“This year has shown me more clearly than ever just how diverse our community is, and how special it is that we can hold so many experiences under this bright umbrella that keeps getting bigger as our community evolves.”  —Oscar R., interactive producer, editorial https://t.co/yAXsZ7e5YE

“For Latinx or anyone who overcame a marginalized background, let’s not just focus on defining us by our origins, but rather by our vision for the future — and how others can help us get there.” —Valerie V., product manager https://t.co/igCmh2QhAa

"When I was a child, my family moved from Mexico to a small town in California. My sister dedicated her time to school and was the first in our family to study at MIT. Following her example came naturally to me, and she still inspires me today.” —Jose Z., software engineer https://t.co/UvJqegYvuX

“I cherish the moments I meet someone and find out they too are from El Salvador or speak Spanish or have lived through similar experiences. Being Latinx is an instant connection you have with others and that's very special.” —Mary V., multicultural communications manager https://t.co/NWxY8h0n3T

“I fully believe that if you see an opportunity, you should go for it. You can believe in yourself to become who you want to be and succeed anywhere. Never let anyone dissuade you. You belong here.” —Crystal H., partner operations specialist https://t.co/oJSBdOvwSJ

“I often think of a phrase from my dad: “If you’re going to do something, do it well.” This came from his experience in the Dominican Republic and has unlocked many opportunities for me because it pushes me to do my best on every project.” —John A., software engineer https://t.co/QW3wJAzvZz

“My greatest inspiration is my mom, who came to the US at 15 from the Dominican Republic as a post-polio medical refugee. She passed in 2006 and she inspired me to enjoy this one and precious life we have as much as possible.” —Chelsea R., learning and development partner https://t.co/oxQk2efUv6

Today we’re honoring Juneteenth, which commemorates the liberation of the last enslaved African Americans on June 19, 1865. 

Check out our story for ways you can observe this day, including Lives to watch, guides with resources and more. 🖤 

https://t.co/zEs0jnF1DM https://t.co/HtSOnRn7A5

“The stickers I designed show an uplifting point of view of what Juneteenth means to me. I wanted to portray the loving aspect of Juneteenth through the embrace of two people who have love for each other and are building each other up.” –Marco Cheatham https://t.co/wGdEZwHZM5

“When designing these, I wanted to focus on the sensory aspect of shackles and chains. The chains are breaking into confetti for that celebration aspect, and the stars reflect life – a spinoff of patriotism and the magic that comes from breaking those chains.”  –Mina Elise https://t.co/NjElYx9NA7

Here’s the story behind their inspiration, in their own words. 

 “I was drawn to the concepts of joy and solidarity. I feel it’s really important to show how we connect with one another and how together we can heal through these traumatic experiences.”  –Andrea Pippins https://t.co/5ZJuXVnISz

We commissioned three Black artists – Andrea Pippins, Mina Elise and Marco Cheatham – to create stickers that honor what Juneteenth means to them. 

You can use the stickers in stories all month long – and when you do, a black heart will show up on your story ring. 🖤 https://t.co/epD9pX4TaE

RT @UNICEF: You asked. We got you answers.

This #SaferInternetDay, we’ve brought together cyberbullying and child protection experts and t…
We want to create a safe and supportive community for everyone on Instagram. For even more tips, visit: https://t.co/Vgco7yma5R

To give you more control over who can contact you on Instagram, there’s a new way to limit who can send you direct messages. The feature lets only the people you follow message you and add you to group threads. https://t.co/UyhOpcCAZG

We also want to help stop bullying before it happens. If someone writes a potentially offensive comment or caption, they’ll get a prompt saying it’s similar to content that’s been reported for bullying. We’ve found this can encourage people to reconsider what they’re posting.

ICYMI, we’ve also been rolling out more features to help prevent bullying. When you restrict an account, only they can see their comments on your posts. And they can’t see when you’ve read their direct messages or when you’re active on Instagram. https://t.co/dOBhxFAITO

If your account’s been disabled, there’s a new way to appeal in the app. When you try to log in, you’ll see an option to “Request a Review.” Tap it and we’ll review your disabled account and potentially restore it. We'll roll out these features over the coming weeks. https://t.co/W9r6B7dpau

You can also tap “More Options” for suggested actions – like muting, blocking or unfollowing accounts you’ve reported. And if you disagree with our decision on the content, you can request a review and we’ll take a second look.

Now when you report something that shouldn’t be on Instagram (like bullying or offensive content), you can get updates through Support Requests. It’s a new feature in the app that shows you the status of your reports. Go to “Settings”  –> “Support Requests.” https://t.co/6hag2ccKtx
For #SaferInternetDay, we’re sharing some tips on how to stay safe on Instagram and take more control over your experience❤️
